answers.answer: Hi,If one’s parents are suffering from diabetes or heart disease, the risk is definitely more compared to those whose parents are not suffering from the same.I’ll suggest you to get your blood sugar test done(fasting as well as 2 hrs post meal glucose) at least every alternate year if not annually. There’s another test known as HbA1c which can tell the status of the past 3months of glucose status.I’ll also suggest to get a regular examination of blood pressure done (at least annually) and in case you develop any symptoms suggestive of CHF like shortness of breath, weakness, swelling of feet etc, you should consult a physician and will need further tests like ECG, echocardiography for the evaluation of the functioning of the heart.I sincerely hope that helps. Please do keep me posted. Kind Regards.

My mother also died of congestive heart failure, when I was 22.  5 years prior to it she had a massive stroke which impaired her speech and ability to communicate.  We, my  younger sister and I never knew she had fluid in her lungs.  The doctor treating her at the time never checked.  She kept complaining of severe pain in her upper chest from shoulder to shoulder and difficulty breathing when lying down.  The Dr. dismissed it as athritis and bursitis, and we were to young and naive to question a doctor. Don't jump to the conclusion however that you will get these symptoms.  My mother had other factors.  There is a family history of heart disease and she was a smoker and recovered alchoholic (17 yrs. clean and sober), plus her recent stroke.  I hope I helped you if, even a little.  Please DO see a Dr. if you do experience any symptoms of pain, difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest area.  God Bless, and best wishes to you.

The hereditary factor you can not change.  However, you can watch your diet very closely, which will help.  My mom's mother and father both had heart disease.  My mom had 10 siblings.  All siblings and herself had and have severe heart disease.  Know your cholesterol numbers.  What is your LDL?  What is your HDL?  What is your triglyercides? What is your blood sugar?  If the LDL is 100 or below, the HDL is 50 or above, and the triglyercides are 150 or below, get your blood work done every year to watch to see if it goes up.  If it goes up, you can drastically change your diet.  I know that not eating red meat, especially beef drops the LDL and triglyercides tremendously.  I gave up beef 13 years ago.  I know eliminating pork drops the LDL even lower.  Fresh organic vegetables are the best and taste the best.  Canned vegetables contain lots of salt.  Salt is not good for the heart.  Fat and sugar cause Diabetes.  Eating fast food rich in fat causes diabetes.  That is why so many young kids are developing diabetes now.  Vitamin B and Vitamin D is good and a lot of people are not getting enough of these important vitamins.  Brown rice is a good thing to eat and is filling.  Salmon is rich in Omega 3 which is good for the heart.  Read labels and watch for fat or salt content.  I, myself, an concerned about developing heart disease.  My bloodwork is LDL 79, HDL 52, and triglyercides 35.  I went a little too far with the diet changes and became anemic, but have adjusted now and have my hemoglobin up to 16 (which is high).  Another thing to think about is people who have inflammation also can have inflammation in their arteries.  This creates a sticky spot where cholesterol can stick and accumulate.  Make sure that you are aware of any inflammation in your body.  Aspirin can bring the inflammation down.  Lecithin also is a great supplement which helps the heart to maintain healthy slippery arteries, which is what we all need.  Ask your doctor about these factors and make sure that you monitor your health and blood work at least once a year.  Diet, exercise and reducing stress help.  Take care.
